Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Developing Super-resolution Microscopy to Image 'Jumping Genes' in Living Cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
Surprisingly, repetitive 'junk' DNA makes up almost half of the human genome. One of the most common types of these repetitive elements are retrotransposons that can copy-and-paste themselves to other locations. While most are now inactive, there is a subset of these elements that are still mobile. These transposition events can lead to a reorganization of DNA in the nucleus, and have been linked to both aging and cancer, yet how they function remains poorly understood. In order to unravel the function and impact of retrotransposons on the genome new approaches are necessary. Under the direction of Dr. Yujie Sun of Peking University, China, an expert in single-molecule super-resolution optical microscopy, this project aims to develop imaging methods to capture these 'jumping genes' in action in living cells.

Recent advances in targeted genome editing have provided tools to recruit proteins to precise sequences of DNA. A specific locus can be imaged by expression of a nuclease-deficient Cas9 enzyme fused to a fluorescent protein and an RNA adaptor that is complementary to the sequence of interest, referred to as a guide RNA. Transposition events can be captured in cultured human cells by designing guide RNAs to an ectopically expressed long interspersed element-1 transposable element. These events then be captured using single molecule super-resolution techniques such as stochastic optical reconstruction microscopy (STORM), providing information on the kinetics of retrotransposition. This approach can also assess the effects of retrotransposon activity on higher order chromosome structure and nuclear architecture, both of which are important regulators of the transcriptional landscape of the nucleus. These methods can aid in the development of a more dynamic view of the genome, supplementing the wealth of information obtained from DNA sequencing. This NSF EAPSI award supports the research of a U.S. graduate student and is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was focused on developing a novel imaging technique to label mammalian long interspersed elements (LINE-1) at single-molecule resolution. LINE-1 elements are DNA retrotransposons in our genomes that can copy-and-paste themselves to new locations, a process that can have negative impacts on human health by disrupting gene functions. Working with Dr. Yujie Sun of Peking University’s Biodynamic Optical Imaging Center, I sought to harness their expertise using state of the art super-resolution optical microscopes to image DNA to study retrotransposon activity inside living cells. By using tools adapted from the recently developed CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing system specific DNA sequences can be visualized as bright fluorescent dots using a confocal optical microscope. This labeling technique allows for imaging of chromosomal phenomena in living cells, a perspective on our DNA that is important as it has become clear that the nuclei of our cells are not static libraries of genetic information but rather rapidly changing and dynamic environments.

            By assembling a recombinant LINE-1 retrotransposon and inserting a sequence downstream that can be labeled using the CRISPR imaging system, we can learn important things about the activity and mechanism of retrotransposition in our genomes. During the course of this project, I developed genetic constructs that could be successfully imaged using the super-resolution microscopes (Figure 1).  By fusing one of these imaging probes with a LINE-1 retrotransposon I was able to image them inside living cells (Figure 2). Additionally, we designed and assembled a ‘self-destructing’ plasmid sequence to eliminate conflicting imaging signals from plasmids containing retrotransposon sequences. Further expansion and optimization of this existing work will allow for precise observation of retrotransposition kinetics and its effects on chromosome architecture. Development of in vivo nuclear imaging tools will be critical to advancing our understanding of the chaotic and dynamic processes that act on our DNA.
